''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to prusue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a preschooler who has sprouted wings, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212)539-6644.

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to prusue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a preschooler who has sprouted wings, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212)539-6644.

''THE BAD BIRTHDAY,'' a puppet show based on an old Mexican fable about twins from a small village who decide to bake a cake to celebrate their birthday and get into trouble with their greedy neighbors when they run out of ingredients. New Perspectives Theater Company, 750 Eighth Avenue, at 46th Street, Clinton. Tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. Tickets: $6; $5 each for families of three or more. Reservations: (212)730-2030.

''DOO--WOP DRACULA,'' a 1950's-style musical by William Electric black about teenage love and rebellion, with a 22-member cast and 13 musical numbers, asks whether happiness is possible for an Italian and a Transylvanian when a plain Jane falls in love with the rebel Johnny Rave, who is dangerous not because he's a vampire but because he's different. Musical arrangements are by the reed player Harry Mann, and choreography is by Sandra Kaufmann. Tonight and tomorrow night at 10; Sunday at 5 p.m. La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village, (212)475-7710. Tickets: $12.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed simultaneously in Spanish and English), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the old story with a twist. Riding Hood does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to have an identity crisis. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Today at 3:30 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. Los Kabayitos Theater, second floor, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $10; $8 children. Reservations: (212)260-4080, Extension 14.

''THE LAND OF SMILES,'' a musical with rod and hand puppets by the puppeteer-singer Susan Delery Whedon, with characters like Griti the Gremlin and Freddy the Frown. Today and tomorrow at noon and 1:30 p.m. Papageno Puppet Theater, 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street, Manhattan. tickets: $6. Reservations required: (212)874-3297.

''THE TORTOISE AND THE HARE'' and other Aesop's fables, including ''Androcles and the Lion'' and ''The Milkmaid and Her Pail,'' by Puppetworks, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, Saturdays at 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. (through aug. 26). For ages 3 and older. Admission: $7; $5 for children; $4.25 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations suggested: (718)965-3391.

''UNWANTED: THE VERY UGLY DUCKLING,'' a New Age version of the Hans Christian Andersen story in which the hero, who hatches from an adopted egg, grows up to discover both his inner beauty and his birth mother. Saturdays at 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. through July 1 at 432 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10. Reservations advised. Information: (212)592-4508.
Events

''BEADS, BODY AND SOUL: ART AND LIGHT IN THE YORUBA UNIVERSE,'' an exhibition presented jointly by the Sutdio Musuem in Harlem, (through Sept. 17), and the Museum for African Art, (through Aug. 27), explores 1,000 years of beaded arts in the Yoruba culture, includig thrones, necklaces and divination beads. The Studio Museum in Harlem, which traces the Yoruba culture in the United States, Brazil and Cuba from the 19th century through the present day, will present a workshop tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. on creating figures of Orishas, which are gods of the Yoruba spiritual world, from cloth and beads. For ages 6 and older. 144 West 125th St., (212)864-4500, Extension 230. Free with admission: suggested donation is $5 for adults; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. The exhibition at the Museum for African Art, which highlights Yoruba traditions in Nigeria from the 11th to the 19th centuries, will present two programs tomorrow: at 1 p.m. the artist Zenzele Browne will help youngsters 5 and older create mixed-media paintings inspired by Orishas (limited to 30), and at 2 p.m. older children can go on a guided tour of the exhibition. 593 Broadway, SoHo, (212)966-1313, Extension 125. Free with admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly. Participants should call to reserve space for all activities.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY. Three workshops will be held tomorrow in the park. From 1 to 2:30 p.m. at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212)860-1370, children 6 and older will collect natural materials on a guided tour and then create their own picture frames. From 1 to 2 p.m. at Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street, (212)772-0210, youngsters 8 and older can learn how to use a compass and map to navigate their way around the Ramble. From 10:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. at the Dairy, mid-park at 65th Street, (212) 794-6564, those 10 and older can enjoy the wonders of nature and participate in a sketching workshop. Free, but call to register for all workshops.

''CIRCUS AMOK.'' Jennifer Miller, the ''bearded lady'' who is the founder and director of the troupe of jugglers, acrobats, stilt walkers, divas and hoop divers called Circus Amok, leads the free urban circus in performances at various parks through Sunday. Tonight at 6 p.m. at United Community Centers, Brooklyn; tomorrow at 4 p.m. at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx; Sunday at 2 and 5 p.m. at Tompkins Square Park, Manhattan. Information: (212)358-5079.

CIRCUS SUNDAYS IN JUNE. Comic magicians, Brazilian stilt-dancers, jugglers and a virtuoso on cowbells will perform final performances tomorrow at 2 and 4 p.m. at the Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge (the historic 1914 Lehigh Valley Railroad Barge No. 79), docked at the foot of Conover Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, rain or shine. A Con Ed shuttle bus will offer a free ride to the barge from Park Slope, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens and Red Hook. Advanced ringside reservations: $5; free seating at show time. Information: (718)624-4719.

''DEADLY WEAPONS,'' a thriller by Laurie Brooks about the consequences of reckless behavior, directed by Graham Whitehead, will be presented as a staged reading today and tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Madougal Street, Greenwich Village. After the Sunday matinee there will be an open forum with the playwright, director, actors and audience. Free. Reservations: (212)998-5867.

''FLAPPING AND CHIRPING,'' After admiring the feathered residents at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., youngsters can create colored clay relief bird creatures. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718)549-3200; reservations: extension 213.

FOLKTALES FOR THE 21ST CENTURY. Stories from around the world, enhanced by puppets, sound effects, musical instruments and various voices, will be presented by the storyteller LuAnn Adams tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens. For children 5 to 12. free. Information: (718)990-0767.

''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' a puppet show by Ellen van Wees with Czech-style marionettes, free, tomorrow at 3 p.m. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212)621-0618 or (212)621-0636. For children ages 4 to 8.

STONE--CARVING DEMONSTRATIONS. Inconjunction with ''The Art of William Edmondson,'' an exhibition of limestone carvings by the artist, the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, will present stone-carving demonstrations tomorrow from 1 to 5 p.m. (also July 29 and Aug. 26). The sculptor Chris Pellettieri will talk about stone carving and at a worktable set with tools and materials show the various stages of carving in stone. Free. Information: (212)595-9533.

''STORYTELLING IN THE GALLERIES: THE FANTASY WORLD OF CARL SANDBURG.'' Carl Sandburg's ''Rootabaga Stories,'' adapted from his classic early 20th-century American fairy tales, will be shared with youngsters tomorrow at 4 p.m on the fourth floor of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718)638-5000.

TRIX CIRCO MUNDIAL, a single-ring circus where stunts, trapeze acts and acrobatics are presented with Latin-flavored live music and costumes, will be presented through July 2 at Macombs Dam Park, 40 East 164th Street, across from Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. Today, Tuesday through Thursday nights at 7:30 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30, 3:30 and 7:30 p.m. For current schedule information, which may change because of the weather, call (888)959-0595. Tickets: $16 to 25; for ages under 10, $14 to $22.50.
Exhibitions

''CAN YOU TELL ME HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET?'' Most children know exactly how to get there: turn on the television set at the right time. An alternative route leads to the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Place, Crown Heights, where in interactive traveling exhibition (through Sept. 3) recreates the set of the PBS series. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 2 to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free, with suggested admission: $4.
